name: Urriðafoss - Iceland's Highest Volume Waterfall
description: Urriðafoss holds the remarkable distinction of being Iceland's highest-volume waterfall, with the mighty Þjórsá river—Iceland's longest at 230 kilometers—pouring approximately 360 cubic meters per second (12,700 cubic feet per second) across a broad curtain of cascades that stretches an impressive 230 meters (750 feet) wide during peak flow periods. Unlike Iceland's famous tall, plunging waterfalls that drop from great heights into misty pools, Urriðafoss presents a different type of spectacle: massive horizontal power as an entire river transforms into thundering whitewater across its full width, dropping a modest but significant 6 meters (12-20 feet depending on water levels) in a series of churning rapids and ledges that create constant roar and spray. The waterfall's name translates to "Trout Falls" (urriða means trout in Icelandic), though the location is equally famous for its salmon runs—Atlantic salmon swimming upstream to spawning grounds must navigate and jump Urriðafoss's turbulent waters, and local legend holds that Þjórsá's salmon population has evolved exceptionally strong and long tail fins specifically to clear this obstacle, a fascinating example of evolutionary adaptation to local conditions. The waterfall's prime location directly beside Iceland's Ring Road (Route 1) just east of the intersection with Route 30 makes it one of the nation's most accessible waterfalls—visitors can literally pull off the highway, walk a few meters to viewpoints, and witness Iceland's greatest water volume in motion without any hiking or 4x4 vehicles required, a convenience that makes Urriðafoss popular with travelers on tight schedules or those unable to tackle more demanding waterfall trails. The volcanic rock ledges and channels that create the waterfall's structure become particularly dramatic in winter when spray and frigid temperatures build up enormous ice formations that can temporarily obscure portions of the falls, creating an otherworldly landscape of frozen cascades and ice sculptures. However, this accessibility and scenic value exists under potential threat: proposals have been made for constructing a hydroelectric power station at Urriðafoss which, if built, would fundamentally alter or potentially eliminate the waterfall by diverting its water flow for electricity generation, making Urriðafoss a case study in Iceland's ongoing tension between renewable energy development and natural landscape preservation. Anglers prize the Þjórsá river both above and below Urriðafoss for trout and salmon fishing, though fishing rights are controlled and expensive given the river's reputation as one of Iceland's premier fishing destinations. The waterfall's width and power are particularly impressive during spring and summer when glacial melt from Hofsjökull and other glaciers in the Þjórsá's watershed swells the river's flow, while late summer and autumn see reduced flow that makes individual rock ledges more visible within the cascade. Photographers find excellent compositions from multiple angles along the accessible shoreline, particularly in evening light when the low sun illuminates the spray and creates rainbows. The location between Hella and Selfoss puts Urriðafoss within day-trip range of Reykjavík (approximately 100 kilometers / 1.5 hours) and en route to southern attractions.
address: Route 1 (Ring Road), near Route 30 junction, South Iceland

opening_hours.fishing: Renowned salmon and trout fishing (controlled access)
